BATTLETECH is a turn-based tactical strategy game developed by Harebrained Schemes and set in the classic MechWarrior universe. It focuses on commanding a squad of customizable BattleMechs in a mix of tactical combat, resource management, and mercenary operations. The game translates the tabletop roots of the franchise into a modern digital format with impressive depth and atmosphere.

Gameplay revolves around commanding a lance of up to four mechs in turn-based missions across diverse planetary environments. Positioning, line of sight, and heat management are critical. Every move carries weight, as overheating, terrain, and armor placement can determine victory or destruction. The combat pace is deliberate, emphasizing careful planning over reflexes.

Customization is one of BATTLETECH‚Äôs strongest features. Each mech can be outfitted with a wide range of weapons, armor configurations, and heat sinks. Balancing weight, firepower, and mobility allows for deep strategic experimentation. The variety of chassis‚Äîfrom light scouts to heavy assault mechs‚Äîencourages diverse playstyles and tactical flexibility.

Outside of battle, the campaign layer adds another dimension. You manage a mercenary company, negotiating contracts, maintaining finances, repairing mechs, and hiring pilots. Decisions made in management affect combat readiness and long-term survival. The economic pressure keeps the experience grounded, making each battle outcome meaningful beyond immediate rewards.

The narrative combines political intrigue and personal stakes within the Inner Sphere. You aid a deposed noblewoman in reclaiming her throne while navigating alliances and betrayals. The writing is grounded and mature, blending military realism with science fiction lore that fans of the franchise will appreciate.

Visually, BATTLETECH presents its universe with grit and realism. The mech models are detailed and weighty, and the combat effects feel impactful without being flashy. The interface is functional but dense, reflecting the game‚Äôs complexity. Audio design‚Äîespecially the heavy mech footsteps and weapon fire‚Äîreinforces the sense of scale.

Overall, BATTLETECH is a deep and satisfying tactical experience. It rewards patience, precision, and strategic thinking. While its pacing may feel slow for players seeking constant action, its depth and atmosphere make it one of the most faithful and engaging adaptations of the BattleTech universe to date. It stands as a must-play for fans of turn-based strategy and mech warfare.

This is a really good game.

If you like a turn based tactics game (I love them) then Battletech is going to scratch that itch in very satisfying fashion.

disclaimer
I have only played the campaign and do not intend to touch multiplayer or career mode.

Pros
My usual gripes are nowhere to be seen. You can skip the intro and splash screens. You can quit to desktop from the pause menu.
The game runs well on a modern rig and I experienced no crashes. Strangely long load times though.
The game play is solid. No mission will take more than about 20 minutes.
The campaign story is your usual betrayal and redemption arc but does it's job of giving you a reason for all your destruction.
Difficulty was surprisingly high at the start but once your lance is at full power there is very little to stop you. This in my opinion is the sweet spot for games. It should be hard to begin with but by the end I should be a god like legend swatting away all comers like flies. Battletech gets this spot on.
The music is good but not spectacular. It is reminiscent of Barber's Adagio for strings (never a bad thing), used in Homeworld. It fits the game very well and an often overlooked part of many games comes in solid here.

Cons
Unity engine always makes me apprehensive.
The game is showing it's age in that it is not graphically very spectacular. If that bothers you then you might be disappointed.
There is a distinct lack of strategy beyond making sure your tonnage is higher than your opponents by some margin. Once you have figured out the basics there is not really a large scope for tactics. Cover seems to be irrelevant and other than attacks from the rear and protecting or targeting damaged zones it seems like there is not a large scope for strategy. That might just be me though.
People looking for a real challenge might want to look elsewhere this is not a hard game beyond a certain point.

Overall well worth the money I paid for it and if you like turn based tactics games this should be on your list.

8/10

This is probably a hoot if you're a Battletech tabletop fan, what with all it's mech building intricacies and vague mechanics that the game absolutely does not bother explaining to you. For me, it just feels like a chore to have several tabs open into rulebooks and hour-long YouTube videos explaining the nuance of combat.

No one wants a massive info dump at the beginning of the game, but surely even an in-game manual would be helpful? So many mechanics are fed to you by brief blurbs from NPCs that largely amount to "you have to manage your heat!" without explaining the numerous ways to do that. Bracing, bulwark, evasion, a whole litany of game mechanics are not properly laid out for you in any way. Normally, I'd say this is beneficial for the sake of trial and error - but error means waiting. And I mean [i]waiting[/i]. As Tom Petty once said, "the waiting is the hardest part."

Injuries and repair times can be mitigated later into the game, but only so much. You'll still spend several minutes on a time advancement screen between battles, even if all goes well, as there is travel involved. What is there to do in that interim? Well, not much. This in and of itself isn't damning, but then there's the combat. Even turning off some extra animations still has battles taking entirely too long for how stale they become. Sometimes it's just turns of sprinting across a generic gameboard to get to an objective before spending 20 minutes firing shots with a slow, itemized list popping up of every affect you inflicted on the enemy mech.

All in all, it's just a bland, slow grind made unbearable by static between everything. The fun of tabletop gaming is the social experience that fills that empty space between turns - this simply takes everything fun from that and serves it up with typically overpriced Paradox DLC.

Although I've been playing Mechwarrior for decades, this was my first time playing Battletech. The trailers looked really good, and most the reviews checked out, so I started playing the vanilla version without any mods.

The gameplay is slow, even for turn based games. The graphics have not aged well. Getting to the various screens you need in the leopard are a pain. Load times are alive and well. There isn't much variety in the missions.

There are some good elements to the game such as the mechlab, the voice acting, and some of the writing. I really appreciate how much difference the terrain makes in this game, compared to MW titles. And melee is actually a viable attack in Battletech! But unfortunately these things are not enough to encourage me to click the Play button again.

This is probably a hoot if you're a Battletech tabletop fan, what with all it's mech building intricacies and vague mechanics that the game absolutely does not bother explaining to you. For me, it just feels like a chore to have several tabs open into rulebooks and hour-long YouTube videos explaining the nuance of combat.

No one wants a massive info dump at the beginning of the game, but surely even an in-game manual would be helpful? So many mechanics are fed to you by brief blurbs from NPCs that largely amount to "you have to manage your heat!" without explaining the numerous ways to do that. Bracing, bulwark, evasion, a whole litany of game mechanics are not properly laid out for you in any way. Normally, I'd say this is beneficial for the sake of trial and error - but error means waiting. And I mean [i]waiting[/i]. As Tom Petty once said, "the waiting is the hardest part."

Injuries and repair times can be mitigated later into the game, but only so much. You'll still spend several minutes on a time advancement screen between battles, even if all goes well, as there is travel involved. What is there to do in that interim? Well, not much. This in and of itself isn't damning, but then there's the combat. Even turning off some extra animations still has battles taking entirely too long for how stale they become. Sometimes it's just turns of sprinting across a generic gameboard to get to an objective before spending 20 minutes firing shots with a slow, itemized list popping up of every affect you inflicted on the enemy mech.

All in all, it's just a bland, slow grind made unbearable by static between everything. The fun of tabletop gaming is the social experience that fills that empty space between turns - this simply takes everything fun from that and serves it up with typically overpriced Paradox DLC.

This is probably a hoot if you're a Battletech tabletop fan, what with all it's mech building intricacies and vague mechanics that the game absolutely does not bother explaining to you. For me, it just feels like a chore to have several tabs open into rulebooks and hour-long YouTube videos explaining the nuance of combat.

No one wants a massive info dump at the beginning of the game, but surely even an in-game manual would be helpful? So many mechanics are fed to you by brief blurbs from NPCs that largely amount to "you have to manage your heat!" without explaining the numerous ways to do that. Bracing, bulwark, evasion, a whole litany of game mechanics are not properly laid out for you in any way. Normally, I'd say this is beneficial for the sake of trial and error - but error means waiting. And I mean [i]waiting[/i]. As Tom Petty once said, "the waiting is the hardest part."

Injuries and repair times can be mitigated later into the game, but only so much. You'll still spend several minutes on a time advancement screen between battles, even if all goes well, as there is travel involved. What is there to do in that interim? Well, not much. This in and of itself isn't damning, but then there's the combat. Even turning off some extra animations still has battles taking entirely too long for how stale they become. Sometimes it's just turns of sprinting across a generic gameboard to get to an objective before spending 20 minutes firing shots with a slow, itemized list popping up of every affect you inflicted on the enemy mech.

All in all, it's just a bland, slow grind made unbearable by static between everything. The fun of tabletop gaming is the social experience that fills that empty space between turns - this simply takes everything fun from that and serves it up with typically overpriced Paradox DLC.
